Quiz.introText: We will ask {count} simple questions to understand exactly where your child is in their development (24-36 months).
Quiz.planSubtitle: Based on your observations, here is what your child needs right now.
Quiz.noSkills: No specific emerging skills observed yet! Keep watching and come back in a week.

gm-running.title: Running with Control
gm-running.prompt: Does your child run confidently and can they stop themselves without falling?
gm-running.description: Child runs without falling and can stop or turn easily.
gm-running.why: Running requires balance and spatial awareness.
gm-running.details: Create 'islands' of color using mats or cushions. Call out a color for them to run to. This builds cardiovascular health and listening skills.

gm-jumping.title: Jumping Off
gm-jumping.prompt: Can your child jump off a low step landing with both feet at once?
gm-jumping.description: Jumping off a low step with both feet together.
gm-jumping.why: Jumping builds core strength and coordination.
gm-jumping.details: Tape a line on the floor. Practice jumping over the 'river'. Keep the landing surface soft and safe.

gm-stairs.title: Alternating Feet (Stairs)
gm-stairs.prompt: Does your child try to go up stairs using alternating feet (not both feet on one step)?
gm-stairs.description: Going up stairs using one foot per step.
gm-stairs.why: Alternating feet is a major milestone in motor planning.
gm-stairs.details: Place a small object on the third step. Encourage them to climb up without putting both feet on the same step. Use a low, safe indoor climber.

fm-scissors.title: Using Scissors
fm-scissors.prompt: Does your child show interest in using scissors or can they make a small snip in paper?
fm-scissors.description: Opening and closing scissors to make a snip.
fm-scissors.why: Cutting is the ultimate test of hand-eye coordination.
fm-scissors.details: Roll playdough into 'snakes'. Let your child snip them into pieces. Using playdough instead of paper provides more resistance and is easier to control.

fm-beads.title: Stringing Large Beads
fm-beads.prompt: Can your child thread a large bead onto a string or stiff lace?
fm-beads.description: Threading a large bead onto a stiff cord.
fm-beads.why: Stringing requires the hand to work in opposition.
fm-beads.details: Use a stiff lace (tip taped) and large wooden beads. Show them how to poke the string through the hole and 'catch' it on the other side.

fm-circles.title: Drawing Circles
fm-circles.prompt: When drawing, does your child make circular marks rather than just scribbles?
fm-circles.description: Making a circular motion with a crayon.
fm-circles.why: Drawing circular shapes prepares the hand for writing.
fm-circles.details: Draw a big circle and ask them to draw 'bubbles' inside. The vertical surface of an easel helps build shoulder and arm strength.

pl-dressing.title: Independent Dressing
pl-dressing.prompt: Does your child try to put on their own shoes or pull up their pants independently?
pl-dressing.description: Putting on simple clothing items like shoes or pants.
pl-dressing.why: Dressing themselves builds self-esteem and independence.
pl-dressing.details: Provide a low chair for them to sit on while putting on pants. Choose elastic waistbands and large openings to ensure success.

pl-table-set.title: Setting the Table
pl-table-set.prompt: Does your child enjoy helping to set the table by placing items in their spots?
pl-table-set.description: Placing a plate or cup in a designated spot.
pl-table-set.why: Contributing to the family meal builds a sense of belonging.
pl-table-set.details: Use a placemat with outlines of a plate, fork, and cup. Show them where each item goes. Let them carry one unbreakable item at a time.

pl-toileting.title: Toileting Interest
pl-toileting.prompt: Does your child tell you when they have a wet diaper or show interest in using the potty?
pl-toileting.description: Showing awareness of bodily functions or interest in the potty.
pl-toileting.why: Toileting is a natural biological progression.
pl-toileting.details: Ensure they can reach the sink and the potty independently. Use a small basket for clean underwear nearby.

lan-sentences.title: Two-Word Sentences
lan-sentences.prompt: Does your child consistently combine two words together like 'Mama go' or 'Big truck'?
lan-sentences.description: Combining two words to express a thought.
lan-sentences.why: Grammar starts with connecting actions to objects.
lan-sentences.details: Repeat their two-word phrases back to them as a full sentence. If they say 'Big truck', you say 'Yes, that is a big red truck'.
